00001 /* 
00002         Issues surrounding threading with Jamoma in general, 
00003         and with objects subscribed to the hub in particular.
00004 
00005         PROJECT CODE NAME: "Be less critical"
00006 
00007         At a minimum we need to define our own mutex for the hub and not use Max's global 
00008         critical region.
00009         
00010         At the moment there are serious concerns about deadock because so much subscriber-related code 
00011         is calling outlet functions from within critical regions.  For example, jcom.init, etc.
00012         Also, critical regions is slow.  So the question is: can we reduce or eliminate them?
00013         
00014         What we know:
00015         * Subscribers are created and deleted only in the main thread.
00016         * jcom.init (need to check this) should always be deferred and thus called in the main thread.
00017         * jcom.message and jcom.parameter can be called from other threads (and thus need some protection)
00018         * not sure about jcom.remote
00019         
00020         What we need to protect against, some scenarios:
00021         * deadlock: jcom.init sends a message to jcom.parameter
00022         * deadlock: jcom.message sends a message out of a module into another module and it bangs a jcom.init
00023         * corruption: jcom.hub is in the middle of traversing the list of parameters to dispatch a message in the scheduler thread
00024                                         in the middle of doing this a parameter is deleted or added in the main thread
00025                                         
00026         Big question: does this whole problem just go away if we switch to using Max's hashtab to manage parameters?
00027         But wait, we need to keep an alphabetized list too.  So in this case it makes sense (and we discussed briefly in Brussels)
00028         that we should keep everything stored in parallel in a linklist and in a hashtab.  Hmmm....
00029         
00030         In Max 5 there is a new dictionary object that does this, but maybe we want something lighter-weight and not as tied 
00031         to the Max API (e.g. for a future Pd port)?  So then make our dictionary...
00032         
00033         So here is one suggestion:
00034         1. we switch to dictionaries to manage parameters
00035         2. we are basically in the same position we are already in
00036         3. oops
00037         
00038         
00039         Here is another suggestion:
00040         The real concern is whether or not subscribers are being deleted or created.  So we add a flag member
00041         to the hub's struct.
00042         * we set the flag anytime we are adding or removing a subscriber from the list
00043         * immediately before dispatching a message we check the flag and abort the dispatch is needed
00044         
00045         This isn't quite as 'perfectly' safe, but actually this the same way it works with Max linklist implementation
00046         where the critical region is buried inside of the linklist access itself, and if the object is deleted after
00047         that access then it's just a message to a bad object (and not the end of the world).  So in fact, it is safe
00048         enough.  Yes?
00049         
00050         This should allow us to avoid the potential deadlock situation.  We should devise an intentional deadlock test first
00051         and then compare before and after to be sure.
00052         
00053         In terms of the speed of the operation for checking the flag instead of entering and exiting the critical region,
00054         my intuition tells me that it will be faster, but I would like to profile it first so we can compare before and 
00055         after.  Probably the best test is some stuff with uzi objects driving parameters.
00056         
00057  */
